content: knot be sure to leave a long tale for sewing then chain 5 this will be your foundation chain single_crochet in the second stitch from hook followed by single_crochet sts in the next 3 sts chain 1 turn row 2- row 29 single_crochet in the next 4 sts chain 1 turn row 30 single_crochet in the next 4 sts *cut end leaving a long tale for sewing pull through center your piece on to the wasp nest and use ends/tales to sew them together note you can make the loop as long or short as you would like by adding or removing row you can make it thinner by shortening your foundation chain if you prefer you can use hemp rope ribbon or anything else you would like to tie on to the top and hang your wasp nest from final dimensions the wasp nest should be about 12 inches long not including loop and about 6 ½-7 inches across from the thickest part up top about 2 inches across from the thinnest part at the bottom the circumference from the center should measure 15 ½-16 inches around it all depends on gauge and how much filling you use etc however gauge does not really matter with this pattern so do not worry if the measurements are not exact you can make size adjustments by using a smaller or larger hook or more/fewer round increases within the basic circle *keep in mind that if you are testing your gauge at the start of your project using a larger hook will increase it by about 2 inches or more also if you use more or fewer round increases this will change the number of stitches you end with in the last round of the basic circle the basic circle is what creates the circumference at the beginning of your project for example the last round of the basic circle for this project is round 10 2 double_crochet sts in the first st 1 half_double_crochet in the next 8 sts = 10 sts repeat 60 sts it ends with 60 stitches if you wanted to continue increasing the next round would end with 66 stitches so you would add your increase before every 9 stiches to create 11 stitches and repeat until you get 66 stitches the round after that would end with 72 stitches so you would add your increase before every 10 to create 12 stitches and repeat until you get 72 stitches
